docs.lead_paragraph: The disintegration of an Iowa forum was the most significant disappointment yet for Mayor Bill de Blasio’s Progressive Agenda Committee, an ambitious but halting enterprise.

byline.original: By ALEXANDER BURNS and MICHAEL M. GRYNBAUM

docs.snippet: The disintegration of an Iowa forum was the most significant disappointment yet for Mayor Bill de Blasio’s Progressive Agenda Committee, an ambitious but halting enterprise....
docs.abstract: New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio's national advocacy group Progressive Agenda Committee is continuing with its ambitious liberal agenda despite number of setbacks it has suffered, including cancellation of presidential forum in Iowa due to lack of interest on part of Democratic candidates.

headline.print_headline: Despite Setbacks, de Blasio’s Advocacy Group Pursues Ambitious Agenda
headline.main: De Blasio’s Advocacy Group Pursues Ambitious Agenda Despite Setbacks

docs.lead_paragraph: Democratic control of state and local elected offices has waned since 2009, hollowing out the party’s roster of potential candidates for major races.

byline.contributor: Sheryl Gay Stolberg reported from Lexington, Michael D. Shear from Washington, and Alan Blinder from Atlanta.
byline.original: By SHERYL GAY STOLBERG, MICHAEL D. SHEAR and ALAN BLINDER

docs.snippet: Democratic control of state and local elected offices has waned since 2009, hollowing out the party’s roster of potential candidates for major races....
docs.abstract: Democratic party, in era of Pres Obama, has greatly diminished in its control of elected offices at state and local levels; Republicans will have 32 governorships in 2016, 10 more than in 2009; Democratic losses in state legislatures during Obama's terms in office are among worst in 115 years.

headline.print_headline: In Obama Era, Wide Republican Gains in States
headline.main: In Obama Era, G.O.P. Bolsters Grip in the States

byline.original: By PATRICK HEALY and GIOVANNI RUSSONELLO

docs.snippet: Despite a month of sharpened attacks from Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont, Mrs. Clinton has support from 52 percent of Democratic primary voters, according to a New York Times/CBS News survey released on Thursday, compared with Mr. Sanders’s 3...
docs.abstract: Despite a month of sharpened attacks from Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont, Mrs. Clinton has support from 52 percent of Democratic primary voters, according to a New York Times/CBS News survey released on Thursday, compared with Mr. Sanders’s 33 percent.

headline.main: Poll Shows Hillary Clinton Maintaining Lead Over Bernie Sanders
